message_1: Given the premises "All mammals are warm-blooded" and "All whales are mammals," use relevance logic to determine whether the following conclusion is valid: "All whales are warm-blooded." (Answer: valid)
message_2:
In relevance logic, we analyze the premises and the conclusion to determine if the conclusion is relevantly entailed by the premises. In this case, we have the following premises:

Premise 1: All mammals are warm-blooded.
Premise 2: All whales are mammals.

We want to determine if the conclusion "All whales are warm-blooded" is valid based on these premises.

To do this, we can use the transitive property of the relation "is a subset of." If A is a subset of B and B is a subset of C, then A is a subset of C. In this case, we can think of the set of whales as a subset of the set of mammals, and the set of mammals as a subset of the set of warm-blooded animals.

Since all whales are mammals (Premise 2), and all mammals are warm-blooded (Premise 1), we can conclude that all whales are warm-blooded by the transitive property. Therefore, the conclusion "All whales are warm-blooded" is valid based on the given premises.
